phrase.item: I am from Wakhan, Namadgut village.
I have been living in Moscow for 20 years.
As I have been living here, in Moscow for all these years, I haven't forgotten my culture and language.
Whatever I know, I pass it to my grandchildren as well to my children.
We Wakhi people use sayings often [in communication], but we don't know the meaning [in depth].
So, I am willing to explain [some] of the meanings of our sayings.
We often use the saying "The one who eats with the wolf cries with the shepherd."
It means a person [has two faces],
a person tells lies in order to fit in.
There is another saying that is used: "Straighten your legs to the length of your blanket."
The meaning being that if your feet come out from your blanket, your feet will feel cold.
It also means — don't think too much of yourself or praise yourself too much.
We Wakhis are such people that no matter how poor we may be, we love guests and always welcome them.
So there is another proverb we have: "Offer your best [well-baked] bread to your guest."
Because of that, no matter whatever we have, in our kitchen, whatever we have for eating in storage, we offer it to guests.
For it is said that all blessings, all barakat, are from guests.
